prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Line widths expected to see in resolved structures (e.g., fragmented cores) are a few km/s. However, we will try to measure the systemic velocity differences of core across the small-scale clumps, which is expected to be 0.1-0.2 km/s. In order to spectrally resolve those small velocity differences with enough number of channels, we request the highest spectral resolutions for all the three dense gas tracers (N2H+, CS, and C33S).

Requested angular resolution is balanced by how much higher angular resolution can be achieved with enough signal to noise ratio from the line observations, especially in N2H+(3-2). Since previous SMA observations show marginally resolved structures with 4" angular resolution, we expect to spatially resolve those structure with requested 1.5" beam (factor of 7 better angular resolution in terms of the surface area). Moreover, our binary survey in OMC using VLT/VISIR, show several of wide-binary separations are 2"-3" (Weber, C. 2015, M.Sc. thesis Univ. Vienna in prep.), so we also expect to spatially resolve those wide binaries in early evolutionary phase. These expected structures might be related to the next hierarchical fragmentation scales and what we aim to observe with ALMA.
Largest angular scale we expect to see is the gas associated with the small-scale clumps, which extends over a few x 0.1 pc. This corresponds to the angular size scale of ~100".

Our sensitivity calculation is driven by the N2H+ (3-2) emission. APEX archival data showed the N2H+ (3-2) spectra toward a core in OMC-3, which showed the peak Tmb~3.8K (Spectra presented in Figure 1F). Adopting the APEX beam size is ~21" and beam filling factor of 1 (uniform intensity distribution; the most strict case), we estimated the expected intensity within the ALMA beam is ~550 mJy/beam km/s. In order to detect this emission peak with ~5 sigma with the requested velocity resolution of ~0.38 km/s, we ask 1 sigma rms noise level of 100 mJy/beam km/s.
With this setting, we will be able to achieve 1sigma rms noise level for continuum of 90 uJy/beam. The mass sensitivity estimated from the noise level is 0.0056 Mo assuming 5 sigma detection. This sensitivity will be more than enough to detect brown dwarf mass sources (0.07Mo) within the system, allowing us to cover the lower end of census within the small-clumps.

Observing settings are exactly same as the first science goal except observing regions. Hence justifications here are same. Please refer details described in the first science goal.

Requested angular resolution is balanced by how much higher angular resolution can be achieved with enough signal to noise ratio from the line observations, especially in N2H+(3-2). Since previous SMA observations show marginally resolved structures with 4" angular resolution, we expect to spatially resolve those structure with requested 1.5" beam (factor of 7 better angular resolution in terms of the surface area). Moreover, our binary survey in OMC using VLT/VISIR, show several of wide-binary separations are 2"-3" (Weber, C. 2015, M.Sc. thesis Univ. Our sensitivity calculation is driven by the N2H+ (3-2) emission. APEX archival data showed the N2H+ (3-2) spectra toward a core in OMC-3, which showed the peak Tmb~3.8K (Spectra presented in Figure 1F). prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Filamentary molecular clouds are ubiquitous in star forming regions. Hence it is crucial to characterize how they collapse and fragment into potential star forming cores.
Our SMA observations toward Orion Molecular Cloud (OMC) identified ~70 dense cores and found that the fragmentation length decreases with decreasing distance to the cluster center (OMC1). These results possibly suggest that filament collapse occurs both locally and globally. However, the lack of kinematical information and limited angular resolution has hampered this study.
In order to study detailed kinematics within local filamentary structures (~0.1 pc scale) and understand nature of local collapse, with 1.5" resolution, we propose to observe four representative local filamentary structures located different parts of OMC using dense gas tracers, N2H+ and CS.
Fragmentation properties and core census will be studied using the continuum emission with 100 times better sensitivities compared to the previous SMA experiments.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
